author: JhoLow1MDB
body:
Agilent: fantastic quality products.  They will be around for forever. Outstanding leadership.  Very diverse industries rely on their products for things like basic research, to food, to diagnostics... it's huge and a stalwart to plug into any portfolio.

Pacific Bio:. There was a reason why Illumina tried to buy PacBio, and I truly believe it is because illumina is scared shitless that PacBio's tech has better advantages.  Next gen sequencing will be used for everything from personalized medicine, to diagnosing cancer, to being fundamental for analyzing results from gene therapies (e.g. CRISPR research). The FTC blocked illumina though from buying PacBio citing anti-competitive issues.  It is kinda crazy how low PacBio is trading at right now.  Read up on NGS tech. PacBio has some serious advantages. 

Applied Materials:. They have competition, but there will be insatiable demand for their products with the advent of 5g, AI, cloud computing and the internet of things.  Last ER they said they had a record backlog of orders for this quarter on top of a record number of orders for this quarter.  A solid play with consistent revenue.

Snowflake: the internet of things will mean a huge demand for data warehousing.  Snowflake also already works with dozens and dozens of big name companies and has basically doubled their earnings every year for the last three years straight. This is a well known IPO coming and may trade like another lofty tech unicorn.

ThermoFisher: an absolute titan in scientific equipment and supplies.  I can't believe they haven't been broken up yet because they control almost everything related to life sciences research. COVID research? Cancer research? Any medical research?  Yeah, at some point you're probably using some product sold or owned by Thermo.  They were just allowed to buy up Qiagen, who is a massive name in PCR and gene analysis. I truly can't believe that was allowed to happen without being blocked for anticompetitive issues. It was a huge aquisition for thermo.  Thermo won't give you explosive gains, but it's one of those slow and consistent ones that just keeps going up slowly over time that may return a lot over the course of 5 years. I can't overstate how massive thermo is for life sciences research.

EnerSys: you know what all of these massive warehouses for E-commerce need for all of this online buying?  Forklifts.  And do you know what forklifts need to run on? Electric only, because you can't use a combustion engine or else there would be risks for carbon monoxide poisoning to warehouse workers.  Enersys makes batteries for forklifts. Someone just posted how the US needs billions of more square feet for handling online commerce.  They will need forklifts. Which need batteries like what EnerSys sells.  In addition, all 5G towers will be required to have battery backups (IIRC). EnerSys makes batteries that will power 5G towers' backup power.  Everyone knows the story about how you need a ton of new 5g towers because of its wavelength, but all of those additional towers will need backup emergency power sources. Hello EnerSys. EnerSys doesn't have the greatest balance sheet at the moment, but there is a lot of potential market for their products.


There are a lot more tech companies out there besides the top 5 or 10 memey ones.

author: wakeandtrade
body:
It's a rental provider network that charges significantly higher contract rates than the rates insurers negotiate themselves, so they're primarily utilized for a couple of reasons. Insurers are expanding into new states and have to meet the regulatory requirements in regards to volume X type of providers available in their network to be able to sell a product there (1 year contract with the rental network aka temporary approach, and then the insurer builds it's own network at better contracted rated and doesn't renew the multiplan rental contract, or 3 year contract with multiplan as touted in the investor slide deck, but the insurer still builds out its own network and just reduces volume of claims sent to muliplan due to a 3 year agreement to reduce the amount paid to providers in regions where they have better contracted rates than multiplan).

The other instance they're utilized by insurers is when certain  provider bad actors (predominantly in anesthesiology and ER) refuse to join the insurer's network with a negotiated payment rate, consolidate with other anesthesiologist groups to be the only game in town, and then leverage their competitive positioning to just charge billed charges (whatever they want to due to no contract) understanding that either the insurer or the patient will have to pay depending on the state law. Many states have legally put the onus on the insurers (particularly if it is a HMO plan) where the insurer must hold the patient harmless and eat costs above what the insurer would typically pay to a contracted provider. So Multiplan may come in with this PPO network that does not provide the balance billing protections to patients like HMO plans do and provides cost assurance to the insurers by bringing the anesthesiolist/ER/etc into the insurer's network through their rental network products. Why would these provider bad actors contract with multiplan or other rental networks? Easy - rental networks will pay  exorbitantly high contract rates to the provider which is still lower cost to the insurer than whatever the provider group decided to bill the insurer when there is no contract, and this provides "savings" to the insurer. This then causes insurers costs to go up which raises premiums for the state's constituents, and becomes a health insurer pain point, patient pain point, and provider pain point for the providers that aren't trying to rip off patients. So now many states have passed anti balance regulation, some states have legislation in process, and legislation has been proposed/is being worked on at the federal level as well. This type of regulation sets an established payment rate between insurers and providers that are out of network (haven't contracted with the insurer) that is still pretty generous, but nothing close to the exorbitant amount rental network will charge to earn that fat margin or what those provider bad actors charge without a contract, and the regulation will stipulate that the providers must accept that as payment in full and cannot bill the patients for a "remaining balance".

Summary: Insurers using a rental network are fundamentally less price competitive to those building their own network because they are paying for the multiplan's margin and a larger margin the provider earns as well...so contracts established with multiplan/\*insert other rental network\* are typically temporary in length or standard in length but insurers are incentivized to send less claims volume to them so less $ made for multiplan and more $ saved for the insurer. Multiplan says it adds value in the commercial space  (employer groups and obamacare), but thats because medicaid and medicare have set payment rates due to the government being the payor and not accepting getting ripped off by significantly higher payment rates than what the government establishes. Anti balance billing regulation eliminates the need for a rental network which is one of the main value props a rental provider network brings.

Then there is also the changing regulatory landscape. If traditional Medicare for all passes, multiplan is basically useless as it's single payer and every provider is now in network being paid on a the medicare fee schedule that adjusts for geographical variations in cost of living, type of service provided, and any other adjustments such as they might try to incentivize more med students to go into primary care due to the shortage etc. Biden's version of Medicare for all doesn't eliminate private/public commercial insurers as you have an option, but it causes large shifts into the marketplace/obamacare products FROM the employer market, so insurers have membership shifts from a higher margin program to a lower margin program, and I would expect Multiplan to have less room to take a middleman margin. But bidens plan also creates a public option which allows for keeping the industry/ jobs (would likely still shrink), but the insurers are now competing against the public option and have to be more cost cognizant. I don't see in this scenario any insurrers really trying to use a rental network and pay multiples of what the public option would pay for the same service at the same location. 

TLDR; BAAAAD DATA CCXX, BAAD DATA - Also this is my opinion but also backed up by publicly available data, legislation, comments submitted during public comment periods on healthcare regulations, state agency positions, and knowing many doctors.

author: jitterbugflash1275
body:
Mmmm... I think everyone goes through such feeling,  unavoidable because it's just human nature. 

From what I know, plan your trade and trade your plan. That probably helps because it sets realistic expectations on your returns.

Also, be cognizant of such feelings washing over you, dont hold it back, but be aware and let it pass. No psychologist myself, but I think that helps with all overpowering emotions.

Also, check out gambler's fallacy while we're on the topic

author: mewtrader
body: I'd naturally agree that it seems rather uncaring, but not knowing him or much about him, I don't reduce him to a rapacious individual, perhaps I could be informed of such, but he could simply be unaware, uninvolved, and indifferent. This is likely more a function of personality that's not directly tied to greed but results in a nonaction that is then perceived as cruelty. You choosing to donate is an active choice. Not giving away your earnings is the default state, a state of nonaction, because in such a state the subject is assumed to be incognizant of any particular demand. The same way you aren't cruel for not having donated to a particular starving child yesterday -- that is a default state of nonaction. Now your brain has become cognizant of the concept of starving children. Reading this, you may or may not choose to donate respondingly. Does not donating make you cruel? Perhaps, perhaps not. It's up to interpretation.

author: rportin
body:
Hold my position, doesn't make sense to sell and owe a bunch of taxes. Even if the market falls, it will just be a buying opportunity with the right companies.

If you are playing the long game, like I am, then November should not matter. There might be some volatility during that time so you should be cognizant of it.

I do admit I am worried about our future with all the spending and loss of wages and countless other incidents happening. November isn't going to instantly fix any of it but it should be a good indicator for what's to come.

There has been a lot of fear base information go out and some of it is logical but where would you put your money. I could pay down the house faster, or increase my savings or put the money into a CD but that would hamper my plans for the future due to the lower yields. Timing the market is not a valid strategy according to historical data for long term investors.

Really there are no other good options unless you are ok with postponing your plans for more safety which is a valid reason.

author: WaldoEmerson89
body:
I’m fully cognizant of my place in the world as far as income vs. the top percentage; but even if we lived in a heavily regulated more leftist society; w/o a doubt putting money into the stock market is an avenue for ppl to grow wealth. 

What I’m trying to say is, “yes the system is messed up as currently is, but also, “don’t hate the stock market when it has had and will continue to have a positive effect for quite literally millions of ppl.” 

I know I’m anecdotal but I feel as if I’m a good example of such success. I’ve been putting money away little by little with my sub-six digit annual salary and I’ve seen fantastic returns in the 3.5 years I’ve been investing.
